summary: This is an email chain from October 2007 discussing negotiations over the selection of a lawyer to represent alleged victims in the Jeffrey Epstein case. The correspondence is between federal prosecutors and Epstein's defense attorney, Jay Lefkowitz, concerning the terms of a proposed letter to a special master (Judge Davis) and the process for victim settlements.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: U.S. Attorney involved in the Epstein case negotiations; referenced as agreeing to terms in the email.

persons.name: Jay Lefkowitz
persons.context: Attorney representing Jeffrey Epstein, negotiating terms for victim representation and settlement process with federal prosecutors.

persons.name: Judge Davis
persons.context: Discussed as a potential special master or attorney to represent the alleged victims; prosecutors state his involvement is a 'non-starter'.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the case; his agreement to pay lawyer fees for victim settlements is discussed.

connections.description: Lefkowitz is negotiating on behalf of Epstein regarding victim settlement terms and legal representation.
Prosecutor Acosta and defense attorney Lefkowitz are corresponding to negotiate terms for victim representation in the Epstein case.
Judge Davis was considered to serve as attorney representative for Epstein's alleged victims, but prosecutors rejected this.

events.title: Deadline for Epstein deal
events.description: Prosecutors set a deadline of close of business for Jay Lefkowitz to agree to the proposed terms for victim representation and settlements.

events.title: Negotiations over victim representation
events.description: Ongoing negotiations between Epstein's defense and federal prosecutors regarding the selection of a lawyer to represent alleged victims and the terms of settlements.

keyFacts: Prosecutors rejected using Judge Davis as the attorney representative for Epstein's alleged victims, calling it a 'non-starter'.
Jeffrey Epstein had agreed to pay the hourly rate for a lawyer working to effectuate settlements for the identified women, but only for that specific work.
Negotiations included concerns about the lawyer's firm size, statutory settlement limits ($150k vs. $50k), and provisions for discovery to test victims' claims.
The email chain shows active negotiation between Epstein's defense and the U.S. Attorney's office in October 2007, with prosecutors pushing to conclude a deal.
